Are you sure it’s ringing without the call being setup?

In my experience I think it’s just silent and only rings when it’s actually connected to the client device?

On my pixel 3 it starts ringing without established connection. Are you sure you are experiencing a different behavior? Cause this is what I found very confusing. If it would be like you describe it, I would be happy with removing the sonar ping

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
Please read this post:

Beta feedback for the upcoming Android 4.33 release Android Beta Feedback
Some background on the sonar ping decision: I’m going to claim that the vast majority of people have no idea what that sound really means. You folks do because you’re in the know, but the average user doesn’t know/care. User’s don’t know/care because other calling apps don’t have this separate sound either, so it can be confusing when they hear it in Signal. It makes call connection times feel longer, even when they’re relatively quick. If you’re ever curious what state you’re in, you can stil…

Frank_x:

If you want proof I can send you tons of debug reports!

I don’t need proof, I have the same problem. But yes, absolutely I want to see some debug-reports. Just because the sonar-sound is gone, does not mean call-setup happens quickly!

And it sounds like you may have enough people, that can reproduce the problem enough of the time, for the problem to finally be nailed down. Please open a new thread about call-setup taking more than 20 seconds every time in the Netherlands, and post debuglogs from both devices, I will definitely read them.

Frank_x:

we have to stop using signal in the netherlands ,because its not reliable [for quick call-setup]…it takes a minimun of 20 seconds to connect[,] average is 30 to 45 seconds. with a call in proges (sub marine sound) this was not a problem now it is!

You can still see on the device, when it is doing call-setup, and when it is actually ringing the recipient’s handset. Old way:

  • signalapp#A would see “Dialing…” on the screen, and play the sonar-submarine-sound as the audio, during call-setup portion
  • signalapp#B would see “[avatar of the caller]” on the screen, and play the ringing-sound as audio
  • signalapp#A would now begin to see “Ringing…” on the screen, and play the ringing-sound as audio (i.e. no longer the sonar-submarine-sound)

This is the new system:

  • signalapp#A would see “Dialing…” on the screen, and play the sonar-submarine-sound ringing-sound as the audio, during call-setup portion
  • signalapp#B would see “[avatar of the caller]” on the screen, and play the ringing-sound as audio
  • signalapp#A would now begin to see “Ringing…” on the screen, and play the ringing-sound as audio (i.e. no longer the sonar-submarine-sound)

You can still figure out when call-setup is taking too long, because you can see right on the screen… it says Dialing during the “sonar phase” (which is now an early-ringing phase), and then it changes to Ringing during the actual ringing-on-both-ends phase.

I only have call-setup problems with certain people, usually ones that are in the EU or ones that are physically far away == high latency. Suggest you just hit the speakerphone button when the phone is “ringing” audibly, and watch the display (which says Dialing at first but Ringing later).

p.s. If you are comfortable with compiling and sideloading, you can probably get the sonar-sound back, but I’m not sure it is that big a deal to just look at the screen? A pain if you are driving a car, but then, you should probably not be trying to signalapp-and-drive simultaneously :-)

Were you using a dutch siomcard?
if not you use your own local infra because roaming is a SS7 tunnel!
well if I call form LTE to my mom who iusing wifi at her work it takes longer … if you stay in 1 provider maby because then you use the 10.x.x.x range as internal IP that’s fast , but if you go over providers its not fast , in NL we have a lot of virtual providers too so if someone is calling from Simple to robin mobile it is the same problem.
If you use a forgn sim in amsterdam you are using your Local country’s IP range you are NOT using the dutch IP range or network , roaming is a SS7 tunnel!

The issue is tat I can but my mother is 70+ and can not read phones display without readiing glasses.

older people can not read the phone screen and need a sound indication!
I ve the feeling that the implcactions were not tought true.
My mother will not be able to use this community , way to complex , so you never hear this.
so you will never know , how opeople of 70+ think and use signal but they do , because they understand privacy , and if you want to talk to family you want talk in private. :

Yes, I agree that the fontsize is a bit small. And this will mean, in turn, that it is harder for your mother, whose eyesight is no longer what it once was, to be able to figure out whether you are just not answering, or whether signalapp is failing to connect. There are probably some specialized screen-reader apps, which will help her out, of course.

In the short run, though, she can preface a call attempt with a textual-message, along the lines of “okay if I call” to which you can reply “sure go ahead”. At least SOME reports on github, of people that were having trouble with call-setup taking too long, suggest that if the caller sends a note, the callee replies to the note and then the callee returns to their conversation-list, that call-setup is much more likely to work speedily. (Not sure this is true, might just be flawed anecdata and confirmation-bias.)

Or she can just listen to the ringing-sound, and if you don’t pick up, capture a debuglog and send the URL over to you.

Frank_x:

I ve the feeling that the implcactions were not tought true.

No, the main signal4android committer explained their reasoning. They don’t believe that most people are having call-setup delays. If you will start uploading pairs of debuglogs, from as many contact-pairs that you know are having trouble with 20+second call-setup, we can help correct that incorrect perception maybe. ;-)

They also don’t believe that everyday folks understand what the sonar-sound actually means, and that is hard to argue with – most people do not understand technology, don’t pay close attention to what their apps behave like, don’t read the helpdocs, and so on. You understood what the sonar-sound meant, and your 70-year-old parent also understood, but it seems likely that is the exception not the rule :-) You are above the curve, and your mom is considerably above the curve, basically.

But the main reason that the change was made, was to “be like other apps” (read: behave exactly like whatsapp behaves) so as to make signalapp less confusing to the target userbase.

Frank_x:

older people can not read the phone screen and need a sound indication!

I think this is only true, so long as signalapp is unreliable during call-setup. If 99.99% of call-setup attempts were completed within four seconds, the sonar-sound would be no use to anybody.

The problem is that signalapp is not anywhere near 99.99% reliable at connecting the webrtc peers in that timeframe. Sometimes it takes 20 seconds, sometimes it takes 60+seconds. The reason that the sonar-sound is useful, is because call-setup needs to be monitored! If call-setup did not need to be monitored closely, the sonar-sound could be honorably retired.

What has happened instead, is that the sonar-sound got retired, but the call-setup problems are still lingering. But regardless of what sound the handset makes during call-setup, methinks I would still argue that the BIGGEST problem is making call-setup four-nines or five-nines reliable within a handful of seconds. Debuglogs will help move closer to that outcome, methinks.

p.s. Like your mom, I’m unable to see the Dialing/Ringing indicators… my eyesight is still good enough, but my handset-model has a bug where signalapp believes the proximity-sensor is being tripped when it is not. Almost as soon as I begin a cryptocall attempt, my screen goes dark black :-) Quite annoying. The workaround is to connect a usb cable and use adb logcat… which might be something you don’t want to try teaching your mother, but then again, she understood what sonar-submarine was about, so she might be able to deal with adb and grep, also! Please convey my apologies to her, that signalapp is being frustrating right now.
